titlestmt.titleproper: Inventory of the Erich Knapp papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Sally DeBauche

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-02-24T14:52-0800
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, financial records, press releases, bulletins, newsletters, serial issues, clippings, other printed matter, and photographs, relating to West German foreign policy, political conditions in West Germany and reunified Germany, political aspects of Islam, and promotion of world peace through Islam.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Erich Knapp papers, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2000.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: 1954-1955: Attended University of Kansas on a Fullbright Scholarship
1955-1957: Studied political science, sociology, and history at Hamburg and Frankfurt Universities
1957-1958: Worked as a journalist at Frankfurter Neue Presse
1961-1963: Worked at IBM Deutschland in Sindelfingen

1963-1974: Served as Press Attaché in the West German Foreign Ministry (Auswärtiges Amt), posted at Bonn, Germany, and subsequently at N’Djamena, Chad; Lagos, Nigeria; Dhaka, Bangladesh; and Cairo, Egypt
1980-1981: Served on executive committee of the German Green Party (Die Grünen)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: This collection documents the political career of Erich Knapp through correspondence, writings, financial records, press releases, bulletins, newsletters, serial issues, clippings, other printed matter, and photographs, relating to West German foreign policy, political conditions in West Germany and reunified Germany, political aspects of Islam, and promotion of world peace through Islam.

The collection contains records primarily related to Die Grünen, the Sozialdemokratische Partei, the German Foreign Ministry (Auswärtiges Amt), as well as a number of other German political organizations. Another main focus of the collection is on Knapp’s advocacy of Muslim communities both in Germany and internationally. He belonged to several organizations that sought to promote religious tolerance and political equality for Muslims, including Tauhid Stiftung, Preussischer Nationalkongress, and Project Musa.

The collection is divided into twenty five series based on form and subject according to Knapp’s involvement in various organizations and political parties. The Correspondence series consists of Knapp’s personal and professional communications with individuals, government agencies, and religious organizations. The Printed Matter series consists primarily of newsletters, journals, magazines, pamphlets, and newspaper clippings related to German politics and culture as well as various religious themes. The Auswärtiges Amt series consists of correspondence and printed matter related to Knapp’s career in the German Foreign Ministry.

There are several series devoted to various members of Knapp’s immediate family, including his mother and father, Philipp Knapp and Luise Knapp respectively, and his wife, Ellen Knapp. A Biographical File consists of Knapp’s personal identification materials and newspaper clippings related to Heppenheim, Germany, Knapp’s place of birth.
The Writings series consists of drafts of essays and books on topics related to politics and religion, as well as handwritten notes on various subjects.
The Photographs and Negatives series consists of photographs, negatives, and photo albums containing images documenting Knapp’s family vacations and political activities.

A handful of series relate to Knapp’s involvement in various German political parties and organizations, including the Aktionprogramm der Sozialistischen Welteuropäischen Partei, the Bund Deutscher Jugend, the Christian Democratic Union of Germany/Christian Socialist Union of Bavaria, the Deutsche Gruppe der Liberalen Weltunion, Die Grünen, Reichsbanner Schwarz-Rot-Gold/Bund Aktiver Demokraten, and various groups advocating for Rheinland Independence.
Lastly a group of series document Knapp’s involvement with various religious organizations, including the Pressischer Nationalkongress, the Tauhid Stiftung, and Project Musa.

Whenever possible, the original folder titles given by the creator have been maintained. Within individual folders, materials have been kept in their original order as accumulated by the creator. Consequently, there is a great diversity in the forms of materials within individual folders; for example, correspondence files often contain newspaper clippings, pamphlets, or other items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence, newspaper clippings, and personal identification documents related to Erich Knapp's mother, Luise Knapp (neé Hunold).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence, newspaper clippings, personal identification documents, and ephemera related to Knapp's father, Philipp Knapp, particulary to his fiftieth anniversary serving as director of the regional health insurance office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of the personal correspondence of Ellen Knapp (neé Rösgen), Knapp's wife.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of personal idenfication documents and other personal items, as well as correpondence, newspaper clippings, and various printed materials related to Heppenheim, Germany, Knapp's place of birth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of family photographs and vacation photographs taken at various locations including Spain, France, Portugal, Morocco, and Switzerland. This series also contains a commemorative collection of photographs documenting the 1936 Olympic Games that took place in Berlin.

did.unittitle: Oversized photograph of unkown German town,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of both personal and professional correspondence with political and religious organizations, government offices, and individuals. Correspondence has been kept in original order as designated by the creator, who at times grouped correspondence together based on subject matter, sender, or format. This series contains four subseries of General correspondence that were arranged alphabetically by the creator according to subject matter or the name of the individual or organization with whom Knapp corresponded.

did.unittitle: From Erich Knapp to Ellen Knapp,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence relating to Knapp's request for access to personal files collected by the former East German secret police, the Stasi. The federal agency tasked with maintaining the files after the reunification of Germany was officially called Der Bundesbeauftragte für die Stasi-Unterlagen, but was often informally refered to by the name of the incumbent commissioner of the office, who at the time was Joachim Gauck.

did.unittitle: Letters of condolence for Luise Knapp's death,
Nazis in the Freie Demokratische Partei,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists primarily of German political, cultural, and religious publications.

did.unittitle: Auf dem Wege nach Weimar und von Weimar nach Potsdam,
"Contre l'Europe germano-americaine et l'election d'un parliament et son service,"
"Dem Deutschen Volk: Der Reichstag in der deutschen Geschichte,"
Der Ewige Bund, newsletter and related correspondence,
Exhibition program and related newspaper clippings,
Die Fehlwege Deutscher Geschichte, with related correspondence,
German and French leftist political writings and related correspondence,
Gustav Heinemann Iran trip controversy and related correspondence,
Internet printouts related to the Taliban,
Der Islam und die Bestimmung des Menschen, photocopy of book,
König der Welt, photocopy of book,
Die Krisis der Neuzeit, photocopy of book,
Martin Walser and Ignatz Bubnis newspaper clippings,
Portugal: Wege und Irrwege, with related correspondence,
Ritualmord als Grundlage/Urdogmas des Christentums und seine Folgen, manuscript,
Various religious pamphlets, newsletters and magazines,
Various German political journals, newsletters, and pamphlets,
Vertrauliche Briefe der Gesellschaft zum Studium der Zeitfragen,
Wir Selbst: Zeitschrift für Nationale Identität,
Aktionprogramm der Sozialistischen Westeuropäischen Partei File,
"Zur Südeuropa - und 3 - Welt - Politik der SPD," essay,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and printed matter related to Knapp's various postings as press attaché for the West Germany Foreign Ministry. This series also contains correspondence, court documents, press releases, and newspaper clippings related to Knapp's dismissal from the Foreign Ministry, an episode dubbed by the German press as the "Knapp Affair."

did.unittitle: "Visit to Cameroon of the President of the Federal Republic of Germany and Madame Luebke," programs,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consisting of correspondence and printed matter related to the Bund Deutshcer Jugend, and political organization of which Knapp was a member.

did.unittitle: Christian Democratic Union of Germany/Christian Socialist Union of Bavaria file,
Deutsche Gesellschaft für Weltfrieden und Ökologie durch Weltföderation file,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and handwritten notes related to the Deutsche Gesellschaft für Weltfrieden und Ökologie durch Weltföderation, an organization founded by Knapp to promote world peace through Islam.

did.unittitle: Deutsche Gruppe der Liberalen Weltunion file,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and printed matter related to the Deutsche Gruppe der Liberalen Weltunion, a political organization of which Knapp was a member.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence related to Tauhid Stiftung, an organization founded by Knapp to promote world peace through Islam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and printed matter related to Die Grünen, the German Green Party, of which Knapp was a member.

did.unittitle: Saarbrücken Kongress correspondence and printed matter,
Nordrhein Westfalen correspondence and printed matter,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of handwritten notes, drafts, and published copies of Knapp's research and articles on various topics primarily related to religion and history.

did.unittitle: Articles in Newsletters, Magazines, and Journals,
"Skizzen zu einer bundesdeutschen Euroasienpolitik," drafts and related correspondence,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and printed matter related to the Preussischer Nationalkongress, an organization to promote political autonomy for the former Prussian state, of which Knapp was a member.

did.unittitle: "Die Macht der islamischen Order," essay and related correspondence,
"Consitutional Declaration Concerning the Re-establishment of the Free State of Prussia,"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and printed matter related to Project Musa, a project initiated by Knapp to advocate for the South African Muslim community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and printed matter related to the Reichsbanner Schwarz-Rot-Gold, a political organization that dissolved and reestablished itself as the Bund Aktiver Demokraten, and of which Knapp was a member.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and printed matter related to various organizations involved with a movement to promote political autonomy of the Rhein region of western Germany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and printed matter related to the Sozialdemokratische Partei of which Knapp was a member.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence and printed matter related to Knapp's university career, in particular his attendence of Kansas University as a Fullbright scholar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of travel guides, maps, and brochures related to Knapp's travels to countries, including Spain, France, Morocco, Switzerland, and Thailand.
